node.name: Josephine Kearns
node.bio: A pioneer in the field of gender consulting, Josie's mission is to get more queer and trans joy - from QTs of all backgrounds - onto stages and screens. (Because really, haven't we had enough trauma porn?) Josie has worked all over the US and Canada as a gender consultant, writer, and creator. As the Consultancy Director for Ring of Keys, she's also excited to help connect others to opportunities. She is energized by the future of queer theatre and eager to connect with others who can say the same.

children.value: Supporting productions centered on transgender, queer, & intersex issues as a member of the artistic team. Josie is also an experienced facilitator who conducts trainings on gender inclusivity.

Josie has been a full-time gender consultant since 2017 and works on medium- to large-scale productions. She has also consulted as an expert in gender with schools, hospitals, businesses, and government institutions, as well as with Actors Equity Association.

node.name: Briyana D. Clarel
node.bio: Briyana D. Clarel is a Black queer writer, performer, and educator passionate about musical theatre, mangoes, and memoirs. Briyana is the founder of The Starfruit Project, a platform supporting radical healing and brilliant growth through creativity. They are the Creative Nonfiction Editor for Homology Lit, a member of the sketch comedy teams The Rhubarbs and Mural Outrage, and a member of Ring of Keys. Briyana’s writing is published in TAYO Literary Magazine, cavity, Black Youth Project, MELANINzine, and print anthologies. As a director, performer, and playwright, they have brought stories to life with the Painted Bride Art Center, OUTsider Festival, Shoe Box Theatre Collective, Cohen New Works Festival, Philly Improv Theater, Theatre Evolve, Dixon Place, Broad Views on Broadway, The Bridge PHL, Cabernet Cabaret ATX, Philly Free Fringe, Aroma Theatre Collective, and more. They are a 2016 recipient of the Acts of Greatness LGBTQ Youth Community Award and a 2018 ASTEP Artist as Citizen Fellow. Born and raised in South Jersey, they hold a BA in Sociology from Princeton University. They love blueberry pancakes, colorful combat boots, and dancing even when people want them to be still. briyanaclarel.com.

children.value: Education around gender and sexuality with an emphasis on race, as well as on building spaces that are both ‘trauma-informed’ and ‘oppression-informed.’

Briyana D. Clarel is a Black queer theatre artist, writer, and educator passionate about musical theatre, mangoes, and memoirs. Briyana is the host of A Very Virgo Virtual Show and the founder of The Starfruit Project, a platform supporting radical healing and brilliant growth through creativity. Briyana’s poetry and prose are published in TAYO Literary Magazine, cavity, Black Youth Project, MELANINzine, and print anthologies. As a director, performer, and playwright, they have brought stories to life with groups in New York, Austin, Chicago, and Philadelphia. Their solo show unboxed: a healing debuted at the 2018 OUTsider Festival. Briyana is a 2016 recipient of the Acts of Greatness LGBTQ Youth Community Award, a 2020-2021 Core Playwright with InterAct Theatre Company, and a 2020 Leeway Foundation Art and Change Grantee. They are one-fourth of Philly sketch comedy team The Rhubarbs. Born and raised in South Jersey, Briyana holds an AB in Sociology from Princeton University. They love sleep, ferns, and taro bubble tea. Keep up with their adventures at briyanaclarel.com and @briyanaclarel.

node.name: Linnea Valdivia
node.bio: Linnea Valdivia is a professional freelance producer, dramaturg and playwright. She holds a B.A. in English from Whitman College with minors in Gender Studies and Theatre and has collaborated on projects with organizations around the country including: The Lark, Oregon Shakespeare Festival, Curious Theatre, Art House Productions, Playwrights Realm and Life Jacket Theatre Company. Linnea is most interested in supporting and creating spaces for new work and underrepresented voices in the arts (with special interest for queer and Latinx stories). She was the inaugural Literary Manager for the National Queer Theatre in NYC and is now based in San Luis Obispo, CA.

children.value: Specialties: Developmental/production dramaturgy and story consulting on work that centers trans/queer narratives and characters with a special interest in new work. She has experience developing materials and policy for organizations seeking to further equity, inclusion and access initiatives.

Experience: Linnea has worked as a dramaturg for organizations around the country and has been a freelance new work consultant since 2018. She is currently pursuing a PhD in Theatre and Drama from Northwestern University.

Specialties: LGBTQ+ and social justice topics in all-ages media. They focus on nuanced representations of gender and sexuality in family-friendly theater and digital media with an eye for intersectional storytelling. They specialize in non-binary identity!

Experience: Lindz is a queer and non-binary creator making LGBTQ+ and social justice media for the whole family through their webseries and their podcast. They travel the country performing original stories and songs at libraries, museums, and schools. Their TED Talk on the importance of talking to young children about gender and sexuality has over 2 million views. Their consulting work ranges from sensitivity readings on picture books for Big Five Publishers, to professional development workshops with educators, school administrators, and librarians, to corporate consulting.

node.name: Rachel Flynn
node.bio:
Rachel Flynn is a director writer, and actor living in New York City. 

She is an enthusiastic creator of new work for theater, music and film, including the devised movement rock concert PATROCLUS, the Supreme Court Punk Show PATRIARCHY, and the upcoming musical Dust & Shadow: Sherlock Holmes and the Jack the Ripper Killings. She is the artistic director of the incubator AT THE TABLE (with Charging Moose Media). Her feature screenplay F@$KING JEFF GOLDBLUM begins production this winter in NYC.

Her consultancy work focuses on women's stories, specifically, and she is a passionate and enthusiastic collaborator on feminist theater in all its forms and made by all people.

She is best known onstage for originating the role of Stoner Chick in Heathers the Musical, and has most recently been seen at Arena Stage (DAVE the Musical), and Alliance Theatre (Ever After the Musical).

She has been described by Time Out New York as "smart and ubertalented," and most of time she is at a diner.

children.value: Specialties: Supporting productions centered on women's issues, gender, queerness and feminism.

Experience: Rachel has over a decade of experience in directing, writing, performance, sensitivity reading, and dramaturgy with a focus on new work in the music theater and theater spaces. She has consulted on productions as a dramaturg, and to support directors and playwrights working on projects with themes of both women's issues and queerness.

node.name: Kevin Paley
node.bio:
Kevin Paley (they/them/theirs) is a non-binary artist working to inspire a more compassionate understanding of humanity. 


Kevin studied acting and directing at the University of Southern California and British American Drama Academy.

Recently, they worked with the Long Wharf Theatre, Transport Group, NAATCO, The Coop, Ivoryton Playhouse, St. Luke's, Stages on the Sound, the Secret Theatre, Open Arts Alliance, The New Ohio, Post Playhouse, Manhattan Theatre Club and Manhattan Repertory Theatre. They also star in Core Ensemble's annual tour of Equally Divine, a solo chamber musical about the Mona Lisa, celebrating gender and sexual fluidity. 

​

 Kevin is the founder of Art Garage, a non-profit dedicated to the work of the Transgender/Gender Non-Conforming community.
node.locations: Denver| Los Angeles| New York City

children.value: Specialties: Director/Producer/Performer specializing in gender, sexuality, and the human condition.

Experience: Kevin has worked with Broadway, Off Broadway, and Regional theatre companies as an assistant to the director and as a gender consultant since 2017. Kevin is the founder and Artistic Director of Art Garage (artgaragenyc.com), a non-profit dedicated to Transgender and Gender Non-Conforming artists.
Queer and trans representation on and off stage
Jasmine is a playwright, director, actor, and producer who runs a theatre company focused on queer/trans theatre. They have consulted on multiple productions around trans identity.

node.name: é boylan
node.bio: Éamon Boylan (they/them/theirs) is a New York City based director, creator, and composer whose recent and upcoming projects include Soft Butter (Ars Nova, Musical Theatre Factory), Waafrika 123 (National Queer Theater), Container (dev. at WP/Public Theater, Rattlestick), Pride Plays (Rattlestick), Memorial (The Lark, LPAC), and Through the Crack in The Closet Door (Corkscrew), Rooms (BAM studio), and The Rite of Spring ​(American Theater Company/CORE Series). They have incubated work with resident artists at LCT3/Lincoln Center, Manhattan Theatre Club, BAM, the O'Neill, Joe's Pub, Clubbed Thumb, Birdland, Playwrights Horizons Downtown, Studio Theatre, NYU Tisch, IRT, Dixon Place, and elsewhere. A graduate of The University of Chicago, Éamon extended their studies in directing at The National Theater Institute and SDCF after completing independent research with Royal Shakespeare Company, Shakespeare Birthplace Trust, and Folger Library Institute. They are a 2019 Trans Lab Fellow, a 2019-20 Sokoloff Arts Resident, a 2019-20 MTC Directing Fellow, member of The Ring of Keys, and a Resident Playwright at Lincoln Center Theater.

children.value: Director/writer/creator/dramaturg, focused especially on non-binary identities and intersections with neurodivergency.

é has consulted on productions as a dramaturg, and in supporting directors and playwrights working on projects with trans themes. They have also organized and participated on panels discussing trans issues in the arts.
